content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" may be cited as the short title. It establishes the Medicare Commission. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, also known as the Commission, is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, also known as the Commission, consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and House Speaker. Members are selected from Senate and House representatives, private citizens, with limits on party affiliation. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and House Speaker. Members are selected from Senate and House representatives, private citizens, with limits on party affiliation. The appointments of the Commission members must be made within 3 months of the enactment of the Act. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The initial meeting must take place no later than 30 days after a specified date. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, consisting of 15 members appointed by various officials, must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission will meet at the Chairman's call, with a majority forming a quorum, and the Chairman being selected from among the members. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, consisting of 15 members appointed by various officials, must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission will meet at the Chairman's call, with a majority forming a quorum, and the Chairman being selected from among the members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program will review analyses of the current financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identify potential problems threatening their solvency, and analyze solutions to ensure financial integrity and provision of health benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program will review the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds and provide recommendations to preserve their solvency. The Medicare trust funds refer to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program will submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will introduce legislation based on the Commission's recommendations. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program will submit a report with recommendations. Legislation must be introduced in the Senate and House of Representatives within 3 months to ensure Medicare trust funds' long-term solvency. If not voted upon within 3 months, the legislation will receive privileged consideration in the House of Representatives. If legislation introduced in the House of Representatives is not voted on within 3 months, the committee it was referred to will be discharged, and a motion to proceed with the legislation will be allowed. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted on within 3 months, the committee it was referred to will be treated as having no further action required. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted on within 3 months, the committee it was referred to will be treated as having no further action required. A motion to proceed to the consideration of the legislation in the Senate will be treated as privileged if no vote on endorsing commission recommendations is taken within the same timeframe. If legislation is not voted on within 3 months in the Senate or House, a motion can be made to consider a joint resolution endorsing commission recommendations and providing legislative authority to implement them. The Commission is granted powers under Section 4. The Commission under Section 4 has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and utilize postal services as needed to fulfill the purposes of the Act. The Commission has the authority to utilize postal services for its purposes. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Compensation of Members: Federal government officers and employees serve without additional compensation, while private citizens serve without compensation for their work on the Commission. The members of the Commission who are not federal government officers or employees are allowed travel expenses and per diem for their services, following rates authorized for agency employees under title 5, United States Code. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative support services upon request. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission. Compensation for staff is determined by the Chairman. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services under specific regulations for rates that do not exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Expenses will be covered by funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
